author: Annabel Ross
title: Joseph McGlennon wins the Bowness Prize, Australia's richest photography award
text:
Joseph McGlennon's Florilegium #1, 2014 , has won the 2015 Bowness Photography Prize. Photo: Joseph McGlennon 
Joseph McGlennon​ has been named winner of the William and Winifred Bowness Photography Prize, Australia's richest photography award.
On Wednesday evening, McGlennon won the $25,000 non-acquisitive prize for his work Florilegium #1 2014 , a richly colourful, intricately layered portrait of two macaws perched on a branch strewn with foliage and flowers, a mountain range visible in the far distance.
McGlennon was inspired by the work of naturalist Joseph Banks, who accompanied Captain James Cook on his 18th-century global travels, collecting botanicals along the way and compiling his findings in a series of copperplate engravings titled Florilegium .
"I approach it like a painting," says McGlennon of his work. "There's probably a hundred layers in this photo."
Advertisement McGlennon, who spends his time between Singapore and Sydney and has worked as a creative director in design and marketing, picked up his camera five years ago after a long hiatus.
"I wanted to get back into it, but in a way different to everyone else," he says. He uses a Hasselblad medium format digital camera to capture his images, which can take over a month to complete, from concept to photography to post-production. He sketches his ideas before setting out to create the scenes he envisages. "I'm not one of those photographers who walks around with a camera all the time," he says. "I make photographs, I don't take them."
One thing McGlennon does carry around is a pair of secateurs.
"I'm literally walking around with a pair of secateurs in my back pocket because you never know when the flowers are out," he says.
"I just pull over and I get out and I start cutting things off trees. I've nearly been arrested a couple of times."
The judging panel for this year's Bowness Prize included artist Bill Henson, Bendigo Art Gallery director Karen Quinlan​ and the Monash Gallery of Art senior curator Stephen Zagala​.
All finalists' photographs will be presented at the Monash Gallery of Art until Sunday, November 22.
